newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish military says outside party politics.
newsitem.headline: Turkish military says outside party politics.

text.p: The influential army, at the centre of a row with the government over Islamist activism, said on Thursday it was steering clear of Turkey's turbulent party politics.
"The Turkish armed forces does not cooperate or favour any personality, political party or group," the military said in a statement carried by the state-run Anatolian news agency.

The military was reacting to a story in the Sabah newspaper that said the generals wanted Deputy Prime Minister Tansu Ciller to win a struggle for the leadership of the Turkish right to ward off the rise of Islamist politicians.
The secularist army has raised its political profile in recent months with a demand that Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan crack down on Islamist activity.
Two ministers from Ciller's True Path Party who sympathise with the army resigned last weekend.

Talks between opposition leaders to form a shadow government that would oust Erbakan have so far borne little fruit and main opposition leader Mesut Yilmaz has indicated it was too early for fresh elections.
Erbakan, modern Turkey's first Islamist leader, had earlier said he was prepared for early polls if necessary.
The military has given Erbakan a list of 18 anti-Islamist measures it wants carried out, including restrictions on Islamist education and enforcement of a ban on Islamic dress.
An Islamist MP close to Erbakan denied he would resign in frustration at Erbakan's reluctance to heed the army.
